thread.title: Melbourne Mayor rebukes 'unacceptable' protesters who turned up at his home
thread.title_full: Melbourne Mayor rebukes 'unacceptable' protesters who turned up at his home

title: Melbourne Mayor rebukes 'unacceptable' protesters who turned up at his home
text:
Angry Melbourne Lord Mayor lashes out at 'mob' over 'unacceptable' protest outside his home Posted February 28, 2017 15:50:46 Map: Melbourne 3000 
Melbourne Lord Mayor Robert Doyle has angrily rebuked protesters who staged a noisy and "threatening" demonstration outside his home on Saturday night over the eviction of homeless people from the city's CBD. 
The noisy "mob" carried banners which said 'Wait till we find your empty summer house' and 'Evicted homeless are at your door, get used to it'. 
Photos of the protest were posted on the website Insurrection News and the faces of the protesters were deliberately obscured. 
Mr Doyle called police and the demonstrators involved in the "unpleasant episode" quickly dispersed. 
The City of Melbourne was under fire in January after it removed protesters who had set up large camps outside Flinders Street around the time of the Australian Open tennis tournament. 
While it is not illegal to be homeless or sleep rough on the streets of Melbourne, it is illegal to camp in a public place. 
As part of the clean-up, the Victorian Government announced a $9.8 million package to help those affected and to move them into transitional housing. Protesters 'crossed the line' 
After a long career in public life, Mr Doyle said he was used to public protests, but the noisy demonstration outside his home upset his wife and two-year-old son and their neighbours. 
"I think though that someone's private home crosses a line that is unacceptable because I'm the one in public life," he said. 
"My wife and two-year-old are not, nor are my neighbours and their children." 
After the protest Mr Doyle's neighbours were letter-boxed with incorrect information about what the city was doing to help the homeless. 
The protesters have also launched a campaign to cover the city's streets in rubbish. 
"I think this was a very irresponsible action and I think that's further underscored by the fact that their published material asks people to come in and trash the city," the Lord Mayor said. 
"I mean that's just unacceptable." 
Mr Doyle said he was talking to police about his security arrangements and would consider taking legal action against them if necessary. 
He said professional protesters had hijacked the cause of the homelessness activists. 
"It wasn't some spontaneous demonstration of homeless people themselves. These were professional protesters," he said.
